author: @xavierthomas1980
text: Hi, a bit late to the party but I think you should not use sleep and neither Press/Release the keys instantly.  The game most probably mange inputs by polling them every frame, pressing/releasing instantaneously will results in most of the key presses not being detected by the game. Sleeping is very crude and blocks the rest of your code which is pretty bad. Have you tried just keeping the key pressed until the next loop iteration?  Edit: Never mind, I went to github and saw the current implementation is doing exactly that.

author: @Alluvian567
text: I know this is late, but I think a serious problem here is that with keyboard you are teaching it very bad habits.  When you turn on keyboard in a game like this you feather the key, so some frames on a turn you have it held down, and on other frames you have your finger off.  Exactly what frames you are on or off the key is fairly arbitrary.  I guess it COULD learn to mimic that feather from scrambled data, but it seems unlikely.  A steering wheel or controller with analog input seems like it would be far better, and a lot more like how an actual car or bike would work.  Watching this for the first time, so this is probably all figured out or overcome.

author: @ryanshrott9622
text: @sentdex I was able to train the alexnet without any memory issues; however, I am not able to load the model into memory when testing the model (I run out of memory). For anyone doing this on a machine with 8gb of ram, I was able to train and test the following version of alexnet with success. I think I will update to 16gb tomorrow. Think that's a good idea?  # alexnet.py  import tflearn from tflearn.layers.conv import conv_2d, max_pool_2d from tflearn.layers.core import input_data, dropout, fully_connected from tflearn.layers.estimator import regression from tflearn.layers.normalization import local_response_normalization    def alexnet(width, height, lr):     network = input_data(shape=[None, width, height, 1], name='input')     network = conv_2d(network, 30, 11, strides=4, activation='relu')     network = max_pool_2d(network, 3, strides=2)     network = local_response_normalization(network)     network = conv_2d(network, 80, 5, activation='relu')     network = max_pool_2d(network, 3, strides=2)     network = local_response_normalization(network)     network = conv_2d(network, 120, 3, activation='relu')     network = conv_2d(network, 120, 3, activation='relu')     network = conv_2d(network, 80, 3, activation='relu')     network = max_pool_2d(network, 3, strides=2)     network = local_response_normalization(network)     network = fully_connected(network, 1000, activation='tanh')     network = dropout(network, 0.5)     network = fully_connected(network, 1000, activation='tanh')     network = dropout(network, 0.5)     network = fully_connected(network, 3, activation='softmax')     network = regression(network, optimizer='momentum',                          loss='categorical_crossentropy',                          learning_rate=lr, name='targets')      model = tflearn.DNN(network, checkpoint_path='model_alexnet',                         max_checkpoints=1, tensorboard_verbose=2, tensorboard_dir='log')      return model

author: @Prophes0r
text: You might want to look into https://github.com/shauleiz/vXboxInterface/releases to create a virtual xbox 360 controller, then use ctypes to call the functions in the vXboxInterface.dll. This way your AI can use a dedicated controller.  OR, you could hack it the same way many PC gamers do by tapping the directional button. Perhaps a PWM style? You may just want to define 25%/50%/75%/100% duty cycles. You may also want to have your control in a separate thread.  NOTE: You might not have as much trouble managing what is/isn't visible to us if you ditch that silly face cam. Sometimes utility is worth more than vanity.

author: @cerpokas
text: I guess model should press the X key, and keep it pressed until it sees that key is not pressed in one of the future frames. author: @VincentChartrand
text: To send weighed commands, you can run a thread several time faster than your image processing. For example if you process a frame every 0.1 s, you can send a command every 0.001 s. You'd be sending a full key press for x % of the time (and no key for (1-x) % of the time. Similar to a PWM.
